English actor

Joseph Matthew Alwyn (born 21 February 1991) is an English actor. He debuted in 2016 with Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk, and has since starred in period films such as Operation Finale (2017), The Favourite (2018), Mary Queen of Scots (2018), and Harriet (2019). Alwyn co-wrote a number of songs by American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift in 2020, such as "Exile" and "Betty". His accolades include the Trophée Chopard at the 2018 Cannes Film Festival and the Grammy Award for Album of the Year with Swift's Folklore (2020).

Early life and education

Joseph Matthew Alwyn was born on 21 February 1991 in Tunbridge Wells, Kent, England.[2][3] Raised in Tufnell Park and Crouch End, North London,[4][5] Alwyn is the son of a psychotherapist mother and a documentary filmmaker father.[6] He is the great-grandson of composer William Alwyn.

He was educated at the City of London School.[4] Although an "introverted" child,[7] he secretly wanted to be an actor[8] and became a member of the National Youth Theatre in his late teens.[9] While studying English literature and drama at the University of Bristol,[7] he acted in two student productions at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.[10] After graduating in 2012, he completed a BA in acting at the Royal Central School of Speech & Drama.[9]

Career

Acting

Within a fortnight of his graduate showcase, in early 2015,[11][12] Alwyn was cast in the lead role of Ang Lee's 2016 war drama, Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk,[13][14] based on Ben Fountain's novel.[15] He had a supporting role in the English drama film The Sense of an Ending (2017).[16]

Operation Finale in August 2018 Alywn at an interview forin August 2018

In 2018, he appeared in Yorgos Lanthimos' award-winning period drama The Favourite[17] and had supporting roles in Operation Finale,[18] Boy Erased,[18] and Mary Queen of Scots.[19] He received the Trophée Chopard alongside Elizabeth Debicki at the Cannes Film Festival that same year.[20] In 2019, he co-starred as slave owner Gideon Brodess in the biographical award-winning drama Harriet, about abolitionist Harriet Tubman[21] which had its world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival on 10 September.[22] In December, Alwyn appeared as Bob Cratchit in the BBC/FX three-part miniseries A Christmas Carol.[23]

In 2021, Alwyn had roles in two films: The Souvenir Part II[24] and the adaptation of Jojo Moyes' book The Last Letter from Your Lover.[25] Alwyn will appear in the Hulu/BBC Three adaptation of Sally Rooney's novel Conversations with Friends alongside Jemima Kirke and Sasha Lane, which is scheduled for a 2022 release.[26] He was initially set to star in the Emily Brontë biopic Emily.[27] In April 2021, he was set to star in comedy film Catherine Called Birdy written and directed by Lena Dunham, based on a novel of the same name by Karen Cushman.[28] In November 2021, Alwyn replaced Taron Egerton in The Stars at Noon opposite Margaret Qualley, directed by Claire Denis.[29]

Music

Alwyn co-produced the songs "Exile", "Betty", "My Tears Ricochet", "August", "This Is Me Trying" and "Illicit Affairs" on American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift's 2020 album Folklore;[30] he also co-wrote "Exile" and "Betty", under the pseudonym William Bowery.[31] Folklore went on to win the Grammy Award for Album of the Year at the 63rd Annual Grammy Awards in 2021.[32] Alwyn (as Bowery) co-wrote "Champagne Problems", "Coney Island" and the title track on Swift's second album in 2020, Evermore.[33]

Personal life

Since 2016, Alwyn has been in a relationship with Taylor Swift.[note 2][38][39]
